preface.title: The Need for Livestock Information Management
preface.para: Either for hunting or husbandry, human beings have always observed and remembered animal movements. Today, with larger herds and more interaction between producers, infrastructure providers, and process auditors more animal movements mean more information for the producer, the provider, and the auditor to manage.

Markets reach peak efficiency when buyers and sellers have an equal or symmetric view of product information.
In 2001, the Nobel Prize in Economics was awarded to George Akerlof, Michael Spence, and Joseph E. Stiglitz "for their analysis of markets constrained by asymmetric information."
How can animal agriculture markets, which are today constrained by an asymmetric information exchange between buyers and sellers be tuned to meet peak potential?
